heading: Scott Morrison speaks to Ukraine PM; 60 Covid deaths reported â€“ as it happened
Australian sanctions on Russia: who do they target and will they have an impact?
text: The Australian government will implement a raft of sanctions against Russia, insisting there â€œmust be consequencesâ€ for Moscowâ€™s recent military actions along its border with Ukraine, and recognition of separatist-controlled regions in the east of the country. Prime minister Scott Morrison unveiled the â€œfirst trancheâ€ of sanctions on Wednesday, bringing Australia in line with the US, UK and European alliesâ€™ initial responses to Russian president Vladimir Putinâ€™s actions in relation to Ukraine.  Australia imposes sanctions on Russia in response to Ukraine crisisRead more Western powers have responded with outrage to Putinâ€™s moves to recognise as independent the republics of Donetsk and Luhansk and send so-called â€œpeacekeepingâ€ troops into Ukrainian territory to secure the new stateletsâ€™ proclaimed borders. Australiaâ€™s sanctions would target specific Russian individuals, corporations and industries in the hope of pressuring the Russian government to stop â€œbehaving like thugs and bulliesâ€, Morrison said. Hereâ€™s what we know about Australiaâ€™s new sanctions on Russia, what theyâ€™re designed to do, and what their impact might be. What are the sanctions? Eight members of the Russian Federationâ€™s security council will be targeted with financial sanctions. Australian law will now prohibit dealing with these individuals financially, as well as facilitating another person to deal with these individuals or assets they own or control. In effect this freezes their assets in Australia â€“ which can include property as well as financial holdings. Travel bans will also be placed on the eight individuals, barring them from entering Australia. Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning Sign up to receive the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning Several Russian financial institutions will also be barred from transacting with Australian banks. The banks are the Russian State Development Bank, VEB, the military bank Promsvyazbank, Rossiya, IS Bank, the General Bank and the Black Sea Bank. Morrison announced Australia would extend sanctions that it already had in place for Crimea and Sevasatopol â€“ Ukrainian territory which Russia annexed in 2014 â€“ to include the breakaway Donetsk and Luhansk regions now recognised as independent by Russia. The expansion of those sanctions would focus on sectors including transport, energy, telecommunications, oil, gas and mineral reserves, Morrison said. What are other countries doing? After Russia announced it would recognise the breakaway regions as independent states and send in â€œpeacekeepingâ€ troops, the US, UK and EU said they would introduce sanctions. The US president, Joe Biden, announced sanctions that target VEB (Russiaâ€™s state development bank) and the Russian military bank, as well as the countryâ€™s sovereign debt and five Russian elites and their families, saying: â€œWho in the Lordâ€™s name does Putin think gives him the right to declare new so-called countries on territory that belonged to his neighbours?â€ Ukrainians ready for resistance: â€˜The whole country will be fighting backâ€™Read more The EU and the UK also announced sanctions in a show of concerted western resolve, with EU foreign ministers banning Russian bond trades in the European market, and the British prime minister, Boris Johnson, unveiling a package of asset freezes on five Russian banks and three individuals. Germany also announced it would halt the approval process for the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline from Russia. Morrison said Australiaâ€™s sanctions â€œensure that we are in lockstep with the United States and the United Kingdom in the sanctions that they are imposingâ€. Both Morrison and foreign powers, including Biden, have warned of a ramp up in sanctions if the situation in Ukraine deteriorates. Whatâ€™s the point of targeting sanctions in this way? The first tranche of sanctions were designed to target â€œpersons and entities of what is termed strategic and economic significance to Russiaâ€, according to Morrison. In relation to the eight members of Russiaâ€™s security council, Morrison said these individuals were being targeted because the body had â€œprovided policy advice and justificationâ€ to Putin which led to him recognising the breakaway republics â€“ a decision which â€œfundamentally undermines Ukraineâ€™s sovereignty and territorial integrity, and it has no validity under international lawâ€. Dr William A Stoltz, from the Australian National Universityâ€™s national security college, said the sanctions â€œclearly focused on pressuring those people who are part of Putinâ€™s inner circleâ€. â€œThese would be the people that we would want to prevail upon Vladimir Putin to take a different course of action â€¦ the people who are powerful enough to put pressure on Putin to retreat, so it makes sense to put the screws on them personally.â€ Will Australiaâ€™s sanctions have an impact? Stoltz said Australiaâ€™s sanctions alone were unlikely to significantly sway Russiaâ€™s behaviours â€“ noting the relatively small trade volumes between the two countries. Is Russia invading Ukraine and what will happen next?Read more â€œOur economic exchange with Russia is pretty small, so we donâ€™t have a great deal of leverage over Russia in that regard.â€ However, he said Australia bringing in similar sanctions to those introduced by the US and European nations was important. â€œFor sanctions to have an effect you need to create a situation where there isnâ€™t a safe haven country for those designated by the sanctions to turn to. So Australia has to be in lockstep with the European and North American countries.â€ If major countries are united, will that be enough? Stoltz is pessimistic that the initial wave of sanctions will have a significant impact. He notes Australia implemented sanctions against Russia in response to the MH17 passenger flight that was shot down while flying over eastern Ukraine in 2014. â€œWe implemented concerted sanctions over MH17, and to put it brutally honestly, theyâ€™ve not been very effective. The Russians still havenâ€™t come to the table for the investigation, theyâ€™ve really prevented justice for the families of the victims,â€ Stoltz said. What more can be done with sanctions? A large part of the ineffectiveness of sanctions against Russia, Stoltz said, had been the countryâ€™s economic resilience to foreign financial punishments. â€œOver the past 20 years Russia has hardened itself to the impact of sanctions, and the Russians are quite used to sanctions by now, they almost wear sanctions like a badge of honour, especially in a situation such as now where theyâ€™re kind of martyring themselves in the national interest,â€ Stoltz said. Oligarchs had previously been the target of foreign sanctions â€“ with their lives in foreign countries upended and assets frozen â€“ in an attempt to pressure them to use their influence over the countryâ€™s leadership. Quick GuideHow to get the latest news from Guardian AustraliaShow Email:Â sign up for ourÂ daily morning briefing newsletterApp:Â download the free appÂ and never miss the biggest stories, or get our weekend edition for a curated selection of the week's best storiesSocial:Â follow us on YouTube,Â Facebook,Â Instagram,Â TwitterÂ or TikTokPodcast:Â listen to our daily episodes onÂ Apple Podcasts,Â SpotifyÂ or search "Full Story" in your favourite appPhotograph: Tim Robberts/Stone RFWas this helpful?Thank you for your feedback. â€œThe oligarchic class has experienced a net falling over them over the past 20 years, over their ability to travel freely and spend their money. Rules have been continuously tightened, and thereâ€™s a sense in Russia that it is hurting that class as theyâ€™re not able to live the luxurious life theyâ€™re used to. â€œSo far that hasnâ€™t affected Putin, who has put in place protections for the oligarchs to get around sanctions â€¦ and technologies like crypto [currency] make it difficult to police the sanctions. But that could stop if he goes too far and sanctions further impact the oligarchic class. He is getting older and he doesnâ€™t have an anointed successor.â€ While western sanctions were designed â€œto influence wealthy elites by stopping them from buying homes and going Christmas shopping overseasâ€, Stoltz said sanctions could go much further. â€œThere is probably going to have to be an attempt to target everyday Russian people, the general population, perhaps by constraining their access to certain everyday goods. Thatâ€™s an ethically challenging thing to do. â€œShort of doing that, economic sanctions against Russia, especially by Australia, are largely symbolic at this point.â€

heading: Australia imposes sanctions on Russia in response to Ukraine crisis
text: Eight senior Russian security officials and the oil and gas sectors will be targeted in the first round of Australian sanctions, with the prime minister vowing to go after anyone â€œaiding and abettingâ€ the invasion of Ukraine. Scott Morrison met with the cabinetâ€™s national security committee on Wednesday before declaring the Russian government was â€œbehaving like thugs and bulliesâ€ and there â€œmust be consequences for Russiaâ€™s actionsâ€.  Morrison characterised the sanctions as only the first step of Australiaâ€™s response and indicated Australian security agencies were on alert for possible counter-actions by Russia such as espionage and cyber attacks. The Russian president, Vladimir Putin, earlier this week recognised the independence of two Russian-controlled territories in east Ukraine and sent in what he called a â€œpeacekeepingâ€ mission. Is Russia invading Ukraine and what will happen next?Read more Australia will begin by imposing travel bans and targeted financial sanctions on eight members of the Russian Federationâ€™s security council â€“ a body that is chaired by Putin and has 12 permanent members including the foreign minister Sergei Lavrov. Morrison did not specify which eight members would be sanctioned, but said the body had provided Putin with policy advice and justification leading to Mondayâ€™s presidential decree that â€œfundamentally undermines Ukraineâ€™s sovereignty and territorial integrityâ€. Australia will also amend its existing sanctions regulations to cover the breakaway regions of Donetsk and Luhansk, prohibiting trade in sectors including transport, energy, telecommunications, oil, gas and mineral reserves. The government says it will broaden the scope of people and entities that Australia can list for sanctions to include those of â€œstrategic and economic significance to Russiaâ€. Australian individuals and entities will be banned from doing business with Rossiya Bank, Promsvyazbank, IS Bank, Genbank and the Black Sea Bank for Development and Reconstruction. This is in addition to restrictions on Australians investing in the Russian state development bank VEB, according to a statement issued by the Australian government late on Wednesday. Morrison acknowledged Australia did not have a large volume of trade with Russia compared with the US and Europe. But he said it was â€œimportant that we play our part in the broader international community to ensure that those who are financing and profiting from an autocratic and authoritarian regime that is invading its neighbour should have nowhere to run and nowhere to hideâ€. â€œAustralians always stand up to bullies,â€ he said. â€œThis is only the start of this process.â€ The announcement follows moves by the US, the UK and the EU to introduce a first round of sanctions. The US president, Joe Biden, said he was determined to â€œcut off Russiaâ€™s government from western financingâ€. Major parties united The major Australian political parties are united on the issue. Senior Labor opposition frontbenchers were briefed by senior officials on Wednesday afternoon. The opposition leader, Anthony Albanese, said he supported the sanctions because Australians should stand united against â€œaggressive Russian action which undermines security in the region and indeed the worldâ€. â€œThe aggressor here is Vladimir Putin,â€ Albanese said in a press conference alongside the shadow foreign minister, Penny Wong. â€œCalling it peacekeeping is quite farcical. It is anything but. This a peace-breaking intervention in violation of international law.â€ After weeks of Morrison telling voters Labor would be weak on national security, Albanese said: â€œWe believe it is important when it comes to national security that we express a common view on behalf of the Australian people.â€ The Greens, too, condemned Putinâ€™s â€œmilitary aggressionâ€ against Ukraine â€œas we condemn all military aggressionâ€. The â€œpeacekeepingâ€ mission means Russia will formally occupy sovereign Ukrainian territory for a second time after the 2014 annexation of Crimea. Putin said on Monday that he saw Ukraine as â€œan inalienable part of our own history, culture and spiritual spaceâ€. â€œThese are our comrades, those dearest to us â€“ not only colleagues, friends and people who once served together, but also relatives, people bound by blood, by family ties,â€ the Russian president said. A military vehicle on a road as smoke rises from a power plant after shelling outside the town of Schastia, near the eastern Ukraine city of Lugansk, on Tuesday after Russia recognised east Ukraineâ€™s separatist republics and ordered the troops there as â€˜peacekeepersâ€™. Photograph: Aris Messinis/AFP/Getty Images Putin had been seeking a range of security guarantees from the west, including curbing the expansion of Nato and a promise that Ukraine would never be able to join the military alliance. But Morrison said on Wednesday accepting such demands from Russia would reduce Ukraine to â€œa nation in name onlyâ€. The prime minister said the Chinese governmentâ€™s language about respecting Ukraineâ€™s sovereignty and territorial integrity had improved over the past week, but Beijing should go further in denouncing Moscowâ€™s actions. He said the Russian government â€œshould be called out as thugs and bulliesâ€. The top official at Ukraineâ€™s embassy in Canberra said his government was grateful for Australiaâ€™s sanctions. Volodymyr Shalkivskyi, the chargÃ© dâ€™affaires at the embassy, told Guardian Australia the impact of the sanctions would â€œdepend on the unity and determination of the international communityâ€ to react to Russian aggression. â€œWe believe that expansion of the sanctions by our international partners is needed in order to deter the Kremlin from further escalation,â€ he said on Wednesday. Ukrainians â€˜top of the pileâ€™ for visa applications Morrison said he had instructed the immigration minister, Alex Hawke, to put 430 Ukrainians citizens who have applied for an Australian visa at â€œthe top of the pileâ€ for a decision. The government was looking at various options for humanitarian support, including through skilled migration and student categories, he said. Any Ukrainian nationals in Australia who have a visa due to expire by 30 June will be granted an automatic six-month extension. On Tuesday, the Australian government directed its officials to leave Ukraine â€œdue to the increased riskâ€. Officials have been deployed to eastern Poland and Romania to provide assistance to Australians who are trying to leave Ukraine. Morrison said Russiaâ€™s ambassador to Australia, Alexey Pavlovsky, was being called to a meeting with the head of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in Canberra on Wednesday â€“ but was not being expelled at this stage. Can anything stop Putinâ€™s advance intoUkraine?Read more He said the Russian government was â€œan autocratic, authoritarian government that has forgotten what democracy is and what liberal democracy isâ€. Pavlovsky denied last month that Russiaâ€™s troop buildup near Ukraineâ€™s border was a sign of aggression and said Australians should look beyond â€œcomic book-style propagandaâ€ about â€œliberal democracies versus autocraciesâ€. At the time, the Russian ambassador said it was wrong to portray Russiaâ€™s concerns about Natoâ€™s eastward expansion as irrational and said any Australian sanctions would be a â€œgestureâ€ with no impact on Moscowâ€™s behaviour. The Russian embassy in Canberra was contacted for comment.

heading: Ukraine president calls up reservists as sanctions coalition against Russia grows
text: Ukraineâ€™s president has called up the countryâ€™s reservists and warned that Ukraine could face a battle for its very existence as more countries joined in sanctions against Russia. Volodymyr Zelenskiy ruled out a general mobilisation in an evening address to the nation. But the decision to bring reservists back into active duty was a further sign that Ukraine was bracing for a possible military clash with its neighbour. It came after Russia began moving troops into the countryâ€™s east.  On Tuesday, Vladimir Putin said that Russia will support the territorial claims of self-proclaimed republics in Luhansk and Donetsk, dramatically increasing the likelihood of a larger war in the near future. Joe Biden denounced the move as an attempt to carve out â€œa big chunkâ€ of the country. The US president said he was bringing in tough new sanctions against Russia for â€œbeginningâ€ an invasion of Ukraine but that there was still time to avoid war. â€œWho in the Lordâ€™s name does Putin think gives him the right to declare new so-called countries?â€ Biden said, announcing sanctions on two Russian banks and sweeping measures to stop Russia raising capital in western markets. Early on Wednesday, Russiaâ€™s US ambassador, Anatoly Antonov, dismissed the sanctions, saying: â€œI donâ€™t remember a single day when our country lived without any restrictions from the western world. We learned how to work in such conditions. And not only survive, but also develop our state.â€ US secretary of state Antony Blinken cancelled a meeting planned for Thursday with Russian foreign minister Sergei Lavrov, saying Russiaâ€™s actions indicated it was not serious about a diplomatic path to resolving the crisis. The White House said a summit between Biden and Putin, proposed by the French president, was â€œcertainly not in the plans at this pointâ€. Speaking alongside Ukrainian foreign minister Dmytro Kuleba in Washington, Blinken warned the crisis was the â€œgreatest threat to Europe since world war twoâ€. He said: â€œ[Vladimir Putinâ€™s] plan all along has been to invade Ukraine, to control Ukraine and its people, to destroy Ukraineâ€™s democracy, which offers a stark contrast to the autocracy that he leads.â€ The warnings came as Australia, Canada and Japan joined the US, UK and European Union in announcing sanctions against Russia and after Germany halted the approval process for the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline. After Boris Johnson, the British prime minister, announced on Tuesday that three billionaire allies of the Russian president and five Russian banks would face punitive measures, his foreign secretary, Liz Truss has written in the Times that the UK is also considering sanctions for members of the Russian Duma and Federation Council, and extending Crimeaâ€™s territorial sanctions to the separatist controlled territories in the Donbas. â€œNo UK individual or business will be able to deal with these territories until they are returned to Ukraine,â€ she said. Truss said the UK was willing to â€œ[turn] up the heatâ€ on a â€œlong listâ€ of people complicit in the actions of the Russian leadership. The UK was willing to introduce other â€œmeasures to limit Russiaâ€™s ability to trade and prohibit a range of high-tech exports, degrading the development of its military industrial base for yearsâ€. Australian prime minister Scott Morrison said on Wednesday the Russian government was â€œbehaving like thugs and bulliesâ€ and there â€œmust be consequences for Russiaâ€™s actionsâ€. Eight senior Russian security officials and the oil and gas sectors will be targeted in the first round, he said, and security agencies were on alert for possible counter-actions by Russia such as espionage and cyber-attacks. Justin Trudeau said Canada was sending hundreds more troops to eastern Europe to bolster Nato forces and imposing new sanctions. The prime minister said: â€œMake no mistake this is a further invasion of a sovereign state and it is completely unacceptable.â€ Trudeau said trade links with the two Russian-controlled territories in east Ukraine would be severed, the purchase of Russian sovereign debt banned, and Russian MPs and state-backed banks targeted. Japan targeted Russian government bonds and trade and people linked to the self-proclaimed republics in Luhansk and Donetsk. â€œWe strongly urge Russia to return to diplomatic process in resolving the development,â€ said prime minister Fumio Kishida. â€˜Weâ€™re not afraid of Putinâ€™: defiance on the streets of KyivRead more For weeks Zelenskiy has urged calm, and a search for diplomatic solutions, even as western allies issued increasingly urgent warnings about Russian invasion plans. Now he has told his country it must â€œincrease the readiness of the Ukrainian army for all possible changes in the operational situationâ€. He added: â€œWe need to promptly replenish the Ukrainian army and other military formations.â€ Zelenskiyâ€™s defiant speech came after the US said on Wednesday that the invasion it had forecast for weeks had finally begun. Zelenskiy said that Ukraine is a peaceful country, but its people would not stay quiet in the face of aggression. â€œIf we remain silent today, we will disappear tomorrow. We have hard work ahead, every day, but we are read for it, with confidence in ourselves, our country and victory,â€ he said. Zelenskiy also said he had held a cross party meeting to propose a defence coalition government and announced the launch of an â€œeconomic patriotismâ€ programme of tax breaks and other incentives to bolster a country battered by the threat of war. Ukraine is losing billions of dollars a month as Europeâ€™s worst security crisis in decades has prompted many who are able to flee the capital, Kyiv, moving to other cities or out of the country entirely. He urged businesses to defy diplomatic warnings to foreign citizens to leave the country, after many embassies moved west to the city of Lviv; US diplomats even sleep in neighbouring Poland and commute to their jobs.

heading: Harsh conditions mean Russian troops near Ukraine will need to be moved soon
text: Russian forces massing near Ukraineâ€™s borders can only remain in position for a few days before they have to be sent back to nearby bases or risk their capability being significantly degraded, western officials and experts believe. That means that President Vladimir Putin will come under increasing pressure to use them in a full invasion of Ukraine â€“ or send them back to staging areas, still in Russiaâ€™s south or west, but tens or even hundreds of kilometres back.  Such advance positions, often with poor protection from the cold, can be held only for a short period â€“ and there is some evidence on social media of the poor conditions endured by soldiers near the border. Postings spotted by military analyst Rob Lee on Monday showed about 100 soldiers camped out â€“ or rather lying down â€“ at a train station about 20km from Ukraineâ€™s border, without rations and having to buy food for themselves. Russian troops based in Belarus, in forests near the town of Khoyniki, 50km from the Ukraine border, were described by one local a few days ago as people who â€œdrink a lot and sell a lot of their diesel fuelâ€, suggesting a lack of discipline despite the heightened political tensions. Western intelligence estimates that roughly a third of the overall Russian forces are now believed to be â€œtactically deployedâ€ in frontline positions â€œpoised for operationsâ€. Their movements have been monitored closely using aerial and other reconnaissance for several weeks, as they edge closer to the border. On Monday, one senior official said they believed it would only be possible for Russia to maintain them in their forward positions for â€œa matter of daysâ€ â€“ a conclusion that is endorsed by independent experts. Nick Reynolds, a land warfare analyst with the Rusi thinktank, said: â€œIf the troops are to be used then they will likely be used very soon, while they are as fresh as possibleâ€ and concurred with the assessment that commanders would want to move them on in â€œa few daysâ€ if they are to be effective. The Guardian view on Ukraine: the shadow of war looms larger | EditorialRead more Latviaâ€™s defence minister, Artis Pabriks, agreed the next few days were crucial. He argued Putin will test western reaction to his recognition of the separatist territories and the formal deployment of Russian forces there. â€œThey will have a small period of reconnaissance and thinking what the west is doing and what the west is planning. They will assess our responses. And if these responses will not be strong enough or convincing enough, then the next stage will be more incidents on the de facto Ukrainian border,â€ he said. It remains perfectly possible for Russia to reverse the frontline deployment and return troops to the staging areas they occupied in January, in a similar way to what happened last spring, ready to escalate at short notice once they have resupplied. But, either way, military pressures mean the next few days are likely to be significant.

heading: Ukrainians ready for resistance: â€˜The whole country will be fighting backâ€™
text: If Russian forces try to take new territory in Ukraine, they will face an army that is far smaller and less well equipped than their own but hardened by eight years of fighting. Nearly a decade of war has also left Ukraine with nearly half a million combat-experienced veterans, many now preparing to fight again, officially or unofficially.  That combination, and the sheer size of Ukrainian territory, means that even if Russia can outgun Ukrainian forces on a conventional battlefield, any military clash could lead to a protracted and bloody partisan conflict. â€œThe Russian army has better weapons and technical equipment than us, so we may lose battles or campaigns. But they can never win the country if the Ukrainian people are motivated,â€ said Serhiy Kryvonos, a retired special forces general and former deputy secretary of the national security and defence council. Kryvonos is travelling the country speaking to veterans and organising weapons training to prepare for a popular uprising should Russia invade. â€œLook at the experience of Afghanistan. It could not be held by the Soviet Union, by the USA, by the United Kingdom,â€ he said. â€œThey could not beat the Taliban because they were well motivated. Their strongest weapon was their partisans, civilians by day, then at night they took up weapons to shoot or bury a bomb in the road.â€ Ukraineâ€™s government, after months of calling for calm, this week shifted its public position and began preparing the country for war. President Volodymyr Zelenskiy announced he was calling up a first group of reservists and on Tuesday the national security council asked parliament to bring in a state of emergency nationwide. Many of those called up had been preparing for weeks, including Roman Nabozhniak, who has made detailed plans for his brownie business to operate without him. Vladimir Putin had brought the country together in the crisis, he said. â€œAmong my friends and peers, there are no arguments now between those who supported Zelenskiy and those who supported [former president Petro] Poroshenko, we have set them aside. Now we have to back this government with one voice. â€œUnity is our most powerful weapon. Russia wants us to have lots of internal arguments they can exploit.â€ Putinâ€™s years of aggressive policy have not only shaped and sharpened national identity â€“ politicians in Kyiv sometimes joke he is a founder of modern Ukraine â€“ but also helped hone the military he may now order Russian soldiers to fight. In 2014, when Russia seized Crimea and Russia-backed forces took control of the east, the Ukrainian army was in such degraded form that soldiers werenâ€™t even getting food. In the years since the collapse of the Soviet Union, discipline had frayed, weapons systems had gone without maintenance for decades, and hardly any of Ukraineâ€™s soldiers had seen combat. â€œThe Ukrainian military in 2014 and the Ukrainian military now are two entirely different things, although without [that army] we wouldnâ€™t have a country at all,â€ said Taras Chmut, a veteran and military analyst with Come Back Alive, an NGO in Kyiv that supports frontline fighters with equipment and training. â€œWe had a big army, with lots of equipment, but it was old and wasnâ€™t in good condition. Food wasnâ€™t getting to the frontline; people were fighting in jeans,â€ he said. â€œEven basic supplies werenâ€™t reaching soldiers, from body armour to first aid kits and communications equipment.â€ 03:20'We're not afraid of Putin': Ukrainians protest in front of Russian embassy in Kyiv â€“ video Today, logistics and training have been improved, and the army has expanded by about 100,000 soldiers, to number about 260,000. Chmut estimates that a total mobilisation including veterans and security forces could put more than 1 million Ukrainians in arms. But when it comes to hardware, Ukraine is still extremely vulnerable. It has a long coastline but, after Russia seized Crimea and its ports, almost no naval capacity. It has no missile defence system, and anti-aircraft defence systems are mostly Russian-made, outdated, and impossible for Ukraine to repair as it cannot get parts. If Russia gains control of the skies over Ukraine, Chmut says he fears civilian slaughter like that seen in parts of Syria, where Russian weapons were used in rebel-held areas. â€œWe are trying to highlight that we need to work on strengthening our air force,â€ he said. â€œIt doesnâ€™t matter how many people are ready to fight: if the enemy control the airspace, it could be like in Syria, bombing of towns and cities with [a] great number of deaths among civilians.â€ Kryvonos was concerned that civilians could be targeted with punitive measures, even if they were not targeted by weapons. â€œThey donâ€™t even need to open fire. You can cut off Kyivâ€™s electricity outside the city,â€ he said. â€œThe larger the city, the easier to create panic and bring it to its knees. If you cut off power it will become a nightmare in a few days, with no water and no heat.â€ He said governments had not done enough to warn civilians to prepare supplies of food and water, or even put up signs to bomb shelters. That is particularly worrying because in addition to Russiaâ€™s superior force of arms in conventional airspace, it could unleash devastating cyberattacks that would make it harder for Ukrainians to access information as any invasion unfolds. While the government is not moving fast enough for him and many other Ukrainians, people are making their own plans and preparations for the resistance that Chmut says would follow a Russian attack â€œIf it comes to an invasion, it will be total war like in 1939. The whole country will be fighting back, there will be a massive resistance. The west should know there will be a large number of refugees, too, maybe 5 to 10 million.â€ Those determined to fight include Oleg Sentsov, a film director from Crimea who became a national hero after he was detained in his home city in 2014 and convicted of terrorism in a Russian military court. Human rights groups denounced it as a show trial. He spent five years in Russian jails, including in Siberia where the cold severely damaged his health, before he was released in a prisoner swap in 2019. He says he is ready to fight, even as his latest film, Rhino, is feted at festivals. â€œI will be in uniform. I have some military training and I know how to act in war,â€ he said in an interview at a central Kyiv cafe, hours before Putin announced his plans to recognise breakaway regions of Ukraine. â€œThe main thing I learned in this life is not to be afraid. In such a difficult time, I will not be the person running from my country.â€

heading: Putin orders troops into Ukraine. Now what?
Bidenâ€™s Russia sanctions: why holding back could be part of his strategy
text: Numerologists will be fascinated that Joe Biden began his Ukraine speech on Tuesday at 2.22pm on 22.2.22. The US president, however, was more concerned with his own calculation of the economic and political costs of overreacting â€“ or underreacting â€“ to Russiaâ€™s provocations. Biden thought he would be remembered as the pandemic president, but finds himself commanding the arsenal of democracy in what could become the biggest military assault in Europe since the second world war. The crisis escalated on Monday after Vladimir Putin recognised two breakaway territories in eastern Ukraine as independent entities, an apparent pretext for invasion.  â€œWho in the Lordâ€™s name does Putin think gives him the right to declare new so-called countries on territory that belonged to his neighbours?â€ Biden demanded in the east room of the White House. â€œThis is a flagrant violation of international law, and it demands a firm response from the international community.â€ But the response he delivered did not go as far as some in Washington would have liked, receiving a cautious welcome from Democrats and failing to satisfy Republicans who accuse Biden of appeasement. It was a shot across Putinâ€™s bows but also the work of an administration keeping some of its powder dry. Biden announced sanctions that target VEB (Russiaâ€™s state development bank) and the Russian military bank, as well as the countryâ€™s sovereign debt and five Russian elites and their families. On the last point, the elites â€œshare the corrupt gains of the Kremlin policies and should share in the pain as wellâ€, Biden said. These oligarchs, who live the high life in London and elsewhere, represent a potential Achillesâ€™ heel for Putin. Sheldon Whitehouse, a Democratic senator, told the Guardian last week: â€œI think he depends on having good relations with the big thieving oligarchs because if they all conspired to defeat him, heâ€™d have to do a lot of oligarch killing and theyâ€™d see that coming. His whole world gets pretty well rocked hard. Thatâ€™s his point of weakness: pressure on the oligarchs.â€ For now, Biden threatened tougher steps if Russia â€œcontinues its aggressionâ€ and warned: â€œWeâ€™ll continue to escalate sanctions if Russia escalates.â€ The logic here is that sanctions lose their potency as a deterrent if they are imposed too quickly: if somebody has been punished for something they havenâ€™t yet done, they might as well do it anyway. But with the window for diplomacy rapidly closing, it may soon be too late for deterrence to mean anything. Washingtonâ€™s response did not have as much bite as the European Unionâ€™s . It did not grab attention like Germanyâ€™s steps to halt the process of certifying the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline from Russia â€“ a lucrative deal long sought by Moscow. The US has not severed Russia from the Swift banking system, used to move money around the globe, nor has it imposed export controls, which would have cut Russian firms off from key high-tech equipment and software. Bob Menendez, a Democrat who is chairman of the Senate foreign relations committee, told the MSNBC network that it is â€œa good first tranche of sanctions but cannot be the end of itâ€. Republicans, who have been less opportunistic than usual in dinging Biden over Ukraine â€“ perhaps sensing that the issue does not animate their base â€“ may now be running out of patience with his determination to avoid too much too soon. Kevin McCarthy and other Republican leaders in the House of Representatives issued a joint statement earlier on Tuesday that said: â€œSadly, President Biden consistently chose appeasement and his tough talk on Russia was never followed by strong action. Lethal aid was slow-walked, anti-air and anti-ship capabilities were never directly provided, pre-invasion sanctions proportionate to the aggression Putin had already committed were never imposed, and sanctions on Nord Stream 2 were waived.â€ And Mitch McConnell, the Republican minority leader in the Senate, revived a Republican talking point about the chaotic withdrawal from Afghanistan. He was quoted by Punchbowl News as saying: â€œI donâ€™t believe Vladimir Putin would have a couple of hundred thousand troops on the border of Ukraine had we not precipitously withdrawn from Afghanistan last August, but thatâ€™s where we are. Looking for signs of weakness.â€ The Afghanistan debacle precipitated a decline in Bidenâ€™s approval rating from which he has not yet recovered. But he does appear to have learned lessons from that failure with a policy of radical transparency about intelligence, close coordination with allies and warnings to Americans that there will be no rescue operation in Ukraine. All this has enabled him to play the role of global statesman and seasoned foreign policy hand. It has offered an unexpected boost to Bidenâ€™s promise to reunify Nato after the doubts and disarray of the Donald Trump years. But he may yet take further hits domestically if the crises forced gas prices even higher. â€œDefending freedom will have costs for us as well, here at home,â€ Biden said. â€œWe need to be honest about that.â€ Honesty, however, may not be enough to win over a distracted and divided electorate.

heading: â€˜Putin chose this war,â€™ Biden says as he announces new sanctions â€“ US politics as it happened

Russia invades Ukraine
Bidenâ€™s Russia warnings come to pass â€“ what does the US president do now?
text: For weeks, Joe Biden has issued urgent warnings that a Russian invasion of Ukraine could happen at any moment. The moment came overnight, when Russian troops began attacking Ukraine by land, air and sea. For the US president â€“ increasingly embattled at home by a resurgent Republican party â€“ it was evidence that the White House had largely assessed the Ukraine crisis correctly, even though their preference would have been to be wrong about their predictions of a disastrous war in Europe.  Biden to address nation as Russia invades Ukraine â€“ US politics liveRead more Now the conflict has dumped a huge foreign policy crisis into an already difficult second year in office for Biden, with a likely backlash looming in Novemberâ€™s midterm elections. With few exceptions, though, he largely has the Democratic party behind him and the Republicans are split, with many backing Biden even as others take various potshots at his presidency. But, for the moment, there is the immediate invasion to deal with. On Thursday morning, Biden met in the Situation Room with his National Security Council to discuss the latest developments in Ukraine. He then met virtually with the leaders of the G7, where they agreed to move forward on â€œdevastating packages of sanctionsâ€. Biden was preparing to deliver remarks from the East Room of the White House this afternoon. â€œPresident Putin has chosen a premeditated war that will bring a catastrophic loss of life and human suffering,â€ Biden said in a statement. â€œRussia alone is responsible for the death and destruction this attack will bring, and the United States and its allies and partners will respond in a united and decisive way. The world will hold Russia accountable.â€ Biden has pledged that the US would not send troops to Ukraine, warning that to do so would risk a wider war in Europe. But the US has provided arms supplies and sent additional troops to the Baltic states as part of his promise to â€œdefend every inch of Nato territoryâ€. â€œSacredâ€ was how the US president described the US commitment to Natoâ€™s article 5, in which an attack on any member nation triggers an allied military response. Domestically, the Biden administration has so far been praised for its decision to quickly declassify intelligence, revealing Putinâ€™s secret plans in real time. Though it was not enough to deter Putin, it helped Washington forge a united front against Moscow in the shadow of the administrationâ€™s disastrous withdrawal from Afghanistan last year that left the US weaker in the eyes of many allies and foes around the world. But after multiple high-profile intelligence failures, the USâ€™s assessment proved largely correct. And when Biden said he believed that Putin had already made the decision to attack, it appears he was right. The accuracy of the intelligence shared by the US, and the unity of the transatlantic alliance, may help give the US renewed credibility on the world stage, where Biden has repeatedly warned that democracies are under threat. In Congress, members have broadly condemned Russiaâ€™s attack on Ukraine and urged the Biden administration to implement the long-promised paralyzing sanctions. Many Republicans have criticized the administrationâ€™s response so far as too little too late, even though senators failed to agree to a bipartisan sanctions package against Russia before leaving Washington for a week-long recess. They settled instead for issuing a strongly worded statement. Underscoring the deep polarization Biden faces at home, a number of Republicans tried to blame him for enabling Putin, including many of the same officials who remained silent as Trump praised and flattered the Russian president. â€œI have earlier criticized the president and I will repeat some of that,â€ Senate minority leader Mitch McConnell said Thursday. â€œI think the precipitous withdrawal from Afghanistan in August â€¦ was an invitation to the autocrats of the world that maybe this was a good time to make a move.â€ McConnell nevertheless claimed to be united with Biden. â€œWe are where we areâ€¦ Weâ€™re all together at this point and we need to be together about what should be done.â€ House minority leader Kevin McCarthy, however, made no mention of the US president in a statement condemning Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine as â€œreckless and evilâ€. â€œPutinâ€™s actions must be met with serious consequence. This act of war is intended to rewrite history and more concerning, upend the balance of power in Europe. Putin must be held accountable for his actions,â€ he said. Mitt Romney said: â€˜The â€™80s called and we didnâ€™t answer.â€™ Photograph: Jon Cherry/Reuters In a bizarre interview on Fox News, Donald Trump mistakenly stated that it was the US, not Russia, invading Ukraine. He was quickly corrected, but spent much of the appearance airing old grievances and attacking his successor. Repeating the baseless claim that the election was stolen, Trump concluded: â€œIt all happened because of a rigged election.â€ US stock markets dropped sharply on Thursday as investors waited to hear more about what sanctions Biden would impose on Russia. After the assault began, the price of oil passed $100 a barrel for the first time since 2014, a rise that will drive up fuel prices even as the US wrestles with the worst inflation in decades. Investors were reassured by Bidenâ€™s comments that sanctions would not affect the oil and gas markets and stocks recovered their losses as the oil price fell. US trade with Russia is relatively small but the conflictâ€™s impact on oil prices was driving up gas prices even before the invasion and there will â€“ no doubt â€“ be more troubling days ahead. In a press conference last week, Biden warned Americans that war in Europe would have consequences for US consumers, already suffering from soaring inflation. â€œI will not pretend this will be painless,â€ he said. The federal government has also warned government agencies and operators of critical infrastructure to take proactive security measures against potential cyberthreats from Russia. Biden said he would do everything to alleviate the economic pinch, including to tap the US national oil reserves, which he has already done in his effort to combat the fastest increase in US inflation in three decades. Higher prices pose an immediate political and economic challenge for the president, whose approval ratings have slumped amid rising gas and food prices. Republicans have blamed Democrats for inflation, which is top of mind for voters ahead of this yearâ€™s midterm elections in November. Additional reporting by Dominic Rushe

heading: Video appears to show military vehicles at Chernobyl â€“ video
Russia unleashed data-wiper malware on Ukraine, say cyber experts
text: Cyber experts have identified a new strain of computer-disabling malware unleashed on Ukrainian targets as part of Russiaâ€™s offensive, as the UK government and banks said they were on alert for online attacks. Russia was widely expected to launch a cyber assault alongside its military campaign, and the run-up to the invasion of Ukraine was marked by the deployment of â€œwiperâ€ malware . A distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack, which paralyses websites by bombarding them with spurious information requests, also hit Ukrainian government sites.  On Thursday, requests for volunteers from Ukraineâ€™s hacker underground began to appear on forums in a bid to help protect critical infrastructure and conduct cyber spying missions against Russian troops, Reuters reported, citing two sources. â€œUkrainian cybercommunity! Itâ€™s time to get involved in the cyber defense of our country,â€ one post read. Yegor Aushev, co-founder of a cybersecurity company in Kyiv, told Reuters he wrote the post at the request of a senior defence ministry official who contacted him on Thursday. Aushevâ€™s firm Cyber Unit Technologies is known for working with Ukraineâ€™s government on the defence of critical infrastructure. On Wednesday, ESET Research Labs, a Slovakia-based cybersecurity company, said it had detected a new piece of data-wiping malware on hundreds of machines in Ukraine. ESET said large organisations had been affected, while security experts at Symantecâ€™s threat intelligence team said the malware had affected Ukrainian government contractors in Latvia and Lithuania and a financial institution in Ukraine. ESET has called the malware, which renders computers inoperable by disabling rebooting, HermeticWiper. The NotPetya attack of 2017, which devastated Ukrainian businesses, was a wiper attack that encrypted computers irretrievably and spilled over into other countries, causing $10bn (Â£7.5bn) of damage worldwide. Alexi Drew, a senior analyst at RAND Europe, a research institute, said cyber offensives carried the risk of escalating rapidly if attacks spill over widely into other countries, although in the case of HermeticWiper the malware does not appear to be self-propogating, whereas NotPetya was able to spread. Further attacks, however, could be different, she added. â€œThereâ€™s a history of cyber-attacks not staying where theyâ€™re meant to go. If you look at NotPetya, the splash damage there was significant. There is a danger here of escalation because offensive cyber activity is fundamentally not very good at staying where you put it.â€ Priti Patel said officials were on alert for cyber-attacks and disinformation campaigns from Moscow. â€œAs we monitor developments, we will be especially mindful of the potential for cyber-attacks and disinformation emanating from Russia,â€ the home secretary said. 03:37Why has Putinâ€™s Russia waged war on Ukraine? â€“ video explainer The chief executive of Lloyds Bank, Charlie Nunn, said on Thursday the lender was on â€œheightened alert â€¦ internally around our cyber risk controls, and weâ€™ve been focused on this for quite a whileâ€. Preparation for potential cyber-attacks was discussed in a meeting between the government and banking industry leaders on Wednesday, Nunn added. According to Symantec, the wiper attack that hit Ukraine this week had been planned for some time. One Ukrainian organisation suffered an initial hack in December last year that was related to the recent attack. DDoS attacks were also deployed ahead of the military offensive in order to spread confusion, according to the US cybersecurity firm Mandiant. In a DDoS attack, websites are deluged with vexatious requests for information and become unreachable. The targets on Wednesday included the Ukrainian defence ministry and PrivatBank, Ukraineâ€™s largest commercial bank. â€œItâ€™s not so much the technical disruption, itâ€™s what it does to undermine confidence, like in the financial sector. It gets people quite nervous. Itâ€™s more that kind of secondary impact,â€ said Jamie Collier, a Mandiant consultant, who described a DDoS as akin to stuffing a thousand envelopes through a letterbox every second. However, Dr Lennart Maschmeyer at the Center for Security Studies at the Swiss university ETH Zurich, said Russiaâ€™s cyber strategy so far seemed more improvised. â€œA plausible scenario for more devastating cyber-attacks was that Russia had planned this invasion for a long time, and prepositioned implants across Ukraineâ€™s critical infrastructure in order to cause mass disruptions coinciding with the military invasion. That does not seem to be the case. The cyber operations we have seen do not show long preparation, and instead look rather haphazard,â€ he said. The headline and text of this article were amended on 24 February and 3 March 2022 to make clear that this was a malware incident affecting machines, not a virus.

heading: Biden imposes new sanctions on Russia: â€˜America stands up to bulliesâ€™
text: Joe Biden on Thursday unveiled a fresh round of what he said would be crippling sanctions on Russia after its invasion of Ukraine, declaring that Vladimir Putin â€œchose this warâ€ and that he and his country would bear the consequences. The harsh new sanctions target Russiaâ€™s largest banks and companies, effectively cutting them off from western financial markets, while imposing restrictions on the exports of advanced technology used to power the countryâ€™s military and tech sector.  â€œPutin is the aggressor. Putin chose this war,â€ the US president said. â€œAnd now he and his country will bear the consequences.â€ Part of a coordinated response, Biden said the measures taken by the US and allied nations around the world were meant to â€œmaximize a long-term impactâ€ on Russia, extracting severe costs on Moscow immediately and over time for what Biden called its â€œbrutal assaultâ€ on a sovereign nation. Sanctions against Russia â€“ at a glanceRead more Biden warned that Putinâ€™s â€œdesire for empireâ€ extended beyond Ukraine, saying the Russian leader sought to re-create the former Soviet Union. The president was emphatic in his vow that US troops would not engage Russia in Ukraine, but he again affirmed the US would defend â€œevery inch of Nato territoryâ€. The commitment was underscored by an announcement that Biden had authorized the deployment of additional US troops to Germany as part of Natoâ€™s response. As Biden addressed the nation from the East Room of the White House, the Ukrainian government reported mounting casualties as Russian troops unleashed a punishing offensive on the nation, advancing on the nationâ€™s capital, Kyiv. Bidenâ€™s remarks came hours after he held a virtual meeting with the leaders of Britain, Canada, France, Italy and Japan. European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen, European Council president Charles Michel, and Nato secretary general Jens Stoltenberg were also in attendance. Earlier on Thursday, Biden convened a meeting of the US national security council. 01:21'Putin will bear the consequencesâ€™: Biden addresses Russia's invasion of Ukraine â€“ video In the afternoon, Biden spent an hour on the phone with the Democratic and Republican leaders in Congress, briefing them on the situation in Ukraine and the administrationâ€™s response to date. The White House has been threatening severe sanctions for weeks, in hopes of deterring Putin from waging war on Ukraine. Earlier this week, when Putin made clear he intended to invade, the White House levied an initial â€œtrancheâ€ of sanctions in response. The penalties imposed on Thursday were designed to further destabilize Russiaâ€™s financial system while starving the country of technology critical to its economy and military, such as semiconductors. The US Treasury said the latest round of sanctions against Russia would affect nearly 80% of all banking assets in Russia, fundamentally threatening its economy and weakening the Kremlinâ€™s geopolitical posture. â€œTreasury is taking serious and unprecedented action to deliver swift and severe consequences to the Kremlin and significantly impair their ability to use the Russian economy and financial system to further their malign activity,â€ said Janet Yellen, the Treasury secretary. Touting the unity among allies and partners, Biden said the sanctions would limit â€œRussiaâ€™s ability to do business in dollars, euros, pounds and yen to be part of the global economyâ€. But they are not as forceful as some elected officials in the US and Ukraine have called for, steps that would include removing Russia from the Swift international banking system and targeting Russiaâ€™s energy sector or leveling sanctions against Putin personally. â€œWe demand the disconnection of Russia from Swift, the introduction of a no-fly zone over Ukraine and other effective steps to stop the aggressor,â€ Ukraine president Volodymyr Zelenskiy said in a tweet. On Thursday, congressman Adam Schiff, the chairman of the House intelligence committee, called on the US to â€œdramatically escalateâ€ its response to Moscow and endorsed calls to remove Russia from the international banking system and its ability to access western capital. Biden argued that time was needed to allow the current round of sanctions to take their desired effect, and said the US was â€œpreparedâ€ to impose more severe penalties on Russia. The president defended his administrationâ€™s response. For several weeks, the US has declassified and made public Putinâ€™s secret plans, while moving quickly to blame Russia for a series of cyber-attacks against Ukrainian banks and agencies. The purpose of the approach was to expose the Kremlinâ€™s justification for war as baseless, he said. What is Swift and what would shutting Russia out of it achieve?Read more â€œNow, itâ€™s unfolding largely as we predicted,â€ the president said. Asked by reporters whether he was consulting China to isolate Russia, Biden would not comment. He also said he was working to persuade India to join the western-led push against Russia. Biden said he had no plans to talk to Putin. During the White House briefing on Thursday, White House press secretary Jen Psaki downplayed the threat of a nuclear attack, after Putin warned that countries that interfered with Russiaâ€™s invasion would face â€œconsequences you have never encountered in your historyâ€. Some analysts interpreted Putinâ€™s comments as a warning that he was prepared to use the countryâ€™s nuclear arsenal. â€œWe donâ€™t see any increased threat in that regard at the present time,â€ Psaki said. As thousands of Ukrainians flee the country, Psaki said the US was prepared to welcome Ukrainian refugees to the US, but expected that the vast majority of them would prefer to remain in Europe. She said the US was working to support humanitarian efforts in neighboring countries, where the European Union is preparing for a large number of displaced people. Psaki also said the US was â€œoutragedâ€ by â€œcredibleâ€ reports that Russian soldiers were holding staff hostage at the Chernobyl nuclear site, near Kyiv. â€œThis unlawful and dangerous hostage-taking, which could upend the routine civil service efforts required to maintain and protect the nuclear waste facilities, is obviously incredibly alarming and deeply concerning,â€ she said. â€œWe condemn it and request their release.â€ The US president also urged resolve among the American people, who he said would probably face economic consequences as a result of what Biden called Putinâ€™s â€œnaked aggressionâ€. The US has also warned government agencies and operators of critical infrastructure to take pre-emptive actions to safeguard against a possible Russian cyber-attack. In a stark contrast to Donald Trump, who has repeatedly assailed Biden during the escalating crisis while badly mangling the facts surrounding Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine, Barack Obama called on â€œevery American, regardless of partyâ€ to support the presidentâ€™s efforts to punish the Kremlin. Echoing Biden, Obama acknowledged that there would be economic consequences for Americans, but that it was a â€œprice we should be willing to pay to take a stand on the side of freedomâ€. As Biden has warned throughout his presidency, he said democracies around the world were being tested and threatened by Putinâ€™s â€œsinister vision for the future of our worldâ€. He said there was never a question that the US would respond to Russiaâ€™s assault on Ukraine. â€œThis aggression cannot go unanswered,â€ Biden said. â€œAmerica stands up to bullies. We stand up for freedom. This is who we are.â€

heading: 'Putin will bear the consequencesâ€™: Biden addresses Russia's invasion of Ukraine â€“ video
Ukraine fights for its survival as Putin presses forward
text: Ukraine was fighting for its survival after Vladimir Putin unleashed a punishing offensive on the country that left hundreds dead or injured, and world leaders warned that Moscow had embarked on a dangerous new era of imperial expansion. The continent awoke to the shock of scenes it once believed it had left in the 20th century: helicopters strafing homes outside the capital, long lines of tanks ploughing ever deeper towards Ukraineâ€™s heartland, roads choked with refugees, and civilians huddled in underground stations to escape bombardment.  The west scrambled to respond with a range of new sanctions against Moscow, with the US also announcing it would send 7,000 more troops to Germany to shore up Natoâ€™s eastern borders. But even after the invasion there were divisions on the strength of the response, as Russian forces advanced undeterred by the threats. 01:11Footage shows Russian helicopters engaging with forces in Ukraine â€“ video With ferocious fighting on multiple fronts, Putinâ€™s ultimate war aims were not entirely clear, but they appeared to be ambitious. Russian airborne forces descended on a military base at Hostomel, just outside Kyiv, with the possible objective of forcing open a pathway to the capital. US secretary of state, Antony Blinken said that â€œall evidence suggests that Russia intends to encircle and threaten Kyivâ€. â€œWe believe Moscow has developed plans to inflict widespread human rights abuses â€“ and potentially worse â€“ on the Ukrainian people,â€ Blinken told a meeting of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE). Russian troops were also clearly attempting to cut off Kharkiv, Ukraineâ€™s second city, with a population of nearly 1.5 million, in the east. Russian attacks in Ukraine Ukrainian authorities said one Russian column had seized control of the Chernobyl nuclear plant, the site of Europeâ€™s worst environmental disaster in 1986, and an emblem for many Ukrainians of the incompetent despotism of rule from Moscow. Mykhailo Podoliak, an adviser to the head of the presidentâ€™s office in Kyiv, admitted it was â€œimpossible to sayâ€ whether the site, where the remains of its radioactive reactor core lie buried, was safe. White House press secretary Jen Psaki said the US was â€œoutragedâ€ by credible reports that staff at the plant were being â€œheld hostageâ€ by Russian forces. â€œThis unlawful and dangerous hostage-taking, which could upend the routine civil service efforts required to maintain and protect the nuclear waste facilities, is obviously incredibly alarming and gravely concerning. We condemn it and we request their release,â€ she said. The port city of Mariupol, which lies between the two regions of Ukraine already occupied by Russia, Crimea and the Donbas in the east, was also reported to be under heavy fire. Ukraineâ€™s president, Volodymyr Zelenskiy, declared martial law and pledged that his government would arm every Ukrainian willing to defend their country. In a late-night address, he said that 137 people had died in fighting, and claimed that Russia had named him â€œtarget number one.â€ As Ukrainian diplomats pleaded with the world to stop the Russian aggression, Zelenskiy warned of a bleak return to the past. â€œWhat we have heard today are not just missile blasts, fighting and the rumble of aircraft,â€ he said. â€œThis is the sound of a new iron curtain, which has come down and is closing Russia off from the civilised world. Our national task is to make sure this curtain does not fall across our land.â€ Many of Putinâ€™s keenest observers had thought the Russian leader would hesitate before ordering an all-out land war to subjugate Ukraine because of the potentially catastrophic consequences for Russia as well as Ukraine, but he proved them wrong. While Russia was chairing an emergency session of the UN security council that was tasked with finding a way out of the crisis the Kremlin had engineered, Putin broadcast a declaration of war he had recorded three days earlier, underlining the futility of the global diplomatic efforts to dissuade him. 03:37Why has Putinâ€™s Russia waged war on Ukraine? â€“ video explainer The US and Europe sought to inflict punitive measures on his regime with the aim of ensuring that Putinâ€™s war of choice became his worst strategic blunder, by crippling the Russian economy. â€œPutinâ€™s aggression against Ukraine will end up costing Russia dearly economically and strategically,â€ Joe Biden warned. â€œWe will make sure of that. Putin will be a pariah on the international stage.â€ Biden said he was sending 7,000 more troops to strengthen Natoâ€™s eastern borders, expelling Russian diplomats, imposing sanctions on Russiaâ€™s two largest banks and almost 90 financial institution subsidiaries around the world. Asked if the invasion marked the start of a new cold war, Biden replied: â€œThat depends. Itâ€™s going to be a cold day for Russia.â€ At the same time, the UK announced its â€œlargest everâ€ set of economic sanctions on Russia, freezing assets of all major Russian banks and limiting cash held by Russian nationals in UK banks and sanctioning more than 100 individuals and entities. However, clear divisions remained among western countries, with the US and European allies concerned about the global economic ramifications of some of the stronger sanctions. Biden admitted for example that exclusion from the Swift global electronic transactions system was not in the present package of sanctions. It was not, Biden said, the â€œposition that the rest of Europe wishes to takeâ€. Nor did the sanctions announced on Thursday include restrictions on Putin himself. The omission of Swift sanctions enraged the Kyiv government. The foreign minister, Dmytro Kuleba, said that those opposing the move had to â€œunderstand that the blood of innocent Ukrainian men, women and children will be on their hands tooâ€. In announcing the sanctions on Thursday, Biden suggested that a wider conflict was possible, given Putinâ€™s aspirations. â€œHe has much larger ambitions than Ukraine. He wants to reestablish the former Soviet Union â€“ thatâ€™s what this is about,â€ he said. Late on Thursday, French president Emmanuel Macron called Putin â€œto demand an immediate haltâ€ to Moscowâ€™s offensive, the Elysee Palace said. The Kremlin, meanwhile, said only that the two leaders had a â€œserious and frank exchange of viewsâ€ about Ukraine. In his speeches, Putin has portrayed the Ukrainian government as a mortal threat to Russia, and hinted heavily at his desire for regime change. He claimed that the Kyiv government had ambitions and means to acquire nuclear weapons, and was run by Nazis â€“ claims so outlandish that they triggered questions about the Russian leaderâ€™s mental stability. By mid-afternoon on Thursday, Russiaâ€™s defence ministry claimed to have â€œneutralisedâ€ Ukraineâ€™s airbases and air defences, destroying 74 military ground facilities, including 11 airfields, three command posts and 18 radar stations for anti-aircraft missile systems. Ukrainian authorities said Russia had carried out 203 attacks and that fighting was raging across almost the entire territory. Military sources in Ukraine said 20 Russian helicopters and Mi-8 aircraft had landed paratroopers at Hostomel airport in the Kyiv region, where forces from both sides were fighting for control. They said Ukrainian forces had killed 50 Russian troops, destroyed four Russian tanks, and downed six Russian planes and four helicopters. Zelenskiy also said Ukrainian forces were fighting to prevent Russian troops capturing the former nuclear power plant at Chernobyl. The early hours of the invasion appeared to have claimed dozens of civilian lives in Ukraine. According to the authorities, 18 people were killed in a missile attack in the southern Odessa region, six people were killed in the town of Brovary, near Kyiv, and four people were killed and 10 injured after an â€œoccupierâ€™s shellâ€ hit a hospital in the city of Vuhledar in Donetsk. Air raid sirens sounded in Ukraineâ€™s major cities, and civilians in Kyiv and Kharkiv sheltered in the citiesâ€™s metro stations â€“ scenes that have not been seen in those cities since 1941. Kuleba urged the world to wake up. â€œPutin has just launched a full-scale invasion of Ukraine,â€ he said â€œPeaceful Ukrainian cities are under strikes. This is a war of aggression. Ukraine will defend itself and will win. The world can and must stop Putin. The time to act is now.â€

heading: US and UK intelligence warnings vindicated by Russian invasion
text: It was in early November that US president Joe Biden took the rare step to dispatch CIA director Bill Burns to Moscow. The spy chiefâ€™s message â€“ in part â€“ was to warn his Kremlin counterparts that the West was concerned about unusual troop movements it was seeing near Ukraineâ€™s border. â€˜Putin chose this war,â€™ Biden says as he announces new sanctions against Russia â€“ US politics liveRead more  British officials were anxious, too. â€œWe keep on coming back to crises over Ukraine,â€ one said later that month. â€œPresident Biden does not send Bill Burns to Moscow unless he is very worried about something. And so, you know, without being able to go into the full details, there is enough substance to this to make us concerned.â€ A few days later, in early December, the Washington Post reported that US intelligence had found that the Kremlin was â€œplanning a multi-front offensive as soon as early next year involving up to 175,000 troopsâ€, from the north, east and south. 03:37Why has Putinâ€™s Russia waged war on Ukraine? â€“ video explainer The intelligence warnings continued into January, increasingly to the irritation of Kyiv, whose president Volodymyr Zelenskiy complained that acute tensions with Russia were nothing new. â€œWe have been in the situation for eight years,â€ he said at the time, referring to the start of the 2014 war with Russian-backed separatists. At the time, some were considered outlandish. Britain warned that Russia was contemplating a coup plot, involving four exiled politicians, while the US said plans were afoot to create a pretext for an invasion using a â€œvery graphicâ€ fake video of a Ukrainian attack. It turned out that Russia did try to create false pretexts, but with none of the production values â€“ or credibility â€“ the US warning implied. The debacle of the buildup to the war in Iraq, where claims of weapons of mass destruction turned out to be baseless, has hung over US and UK agencies for two decades. This time, unfortunately, their warnings about Vladimir Putinâ€™s intentions have proved uncannily accurate.

heading: Sean Penn in Ukraine to film documentary on Russian invasion
text: Actor Sean Penn is on the ground in Ukraine making a documentary about the Russian invasion, Vice Studios confirmed to Variety on Thursday, as Russia began a full-scale attack on its neighbor. The Oscar-winning star and longtime humanitarian activist appeared at a press briefing by the Ukrainian government in Kyiv on Thursday, listening to government officials speak about the crisis many world leaders are calling the worst conflict in Europe since 1945.  Ukraine fighting to stop â€˜a new iron curtainâ€™ after Russian invasionRead more Penn previously visited Ukraine in November 2021 to research for the film. His visits with the Ukrainian military were documented by the Ukrainian joint forces operation press service, which posted photos of the meetups on social media at the time. According to Newsweek, Penn arrived in Kyiv earlier this week and met with deputy prime minister Iryna Vereshchuk, as well as local journalists and members of the military. The office of Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskiy issued a statement through the Ukrainian embassy in praise of the actor and director, who â€œspecially came to Kyiv to record all the events that are currently happening in Ukraine and to tell the world the truth about Russiaâ€™s invasion of our countryâ€. â€œSean Penn is among those who support Ukraine in Ukraine today. Our country is grateful to him for such a show of courage and honesty,â€ the translated statement read. The statement also said Penn â€œis demonstrating bravery that many others have been lacking, in particular some Western politicians. The more people like that â€“ true friends of Ukraine, who support the fight for freedom â€“ the quicker we can stop this heinous invasion by Russiaâ€. This is not the first time Penn has put himself in the center of a crisis. The 61-year-old actor directed the 2020 Discovery Plus documentary Citizen Penn, about the process of establishing his non-profit Community Organized Relief Effort, or Core, in the wake the devastating earthquakes in Haiti in 2010. Core also helped deploy teams for Covid-19 testing and vaccination during the pandemic. In January 2016, Penn published an exclusive â€“ and highly controversial â€“ interview with Mexican drug kingpin JoaquÃ­n â€œEl Chapoâ€ GuzmÃ¡n in Rolling Stone; Pennâ€™s covert journey to visit with the Sinaloan cartel leader, who escaped from prison in 2015, contributed to his arrest by Mexican authorities. Penn later said he had â€œterrible regretâ€ that his interview and 10,000-word article did not achieve its true purpose of changing the conversation about the war on drugs.

heading: â€˜A knot in my stomachâ€™: Canadaâ€™s Ukrainian community shaken by Russia invasion
text: News of Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine has shaken members of Canadaâ€™s Ukrainian community, the largest diaspora population outside of Ukraine and Russia. â€œI have a knot in my stomach. I can only imagine what itâ€™s like for people in Ukraine who are living with the shelling,â€ said Taras Kulish, a Toronto-based charity lawyer and member of the Ukrainian Canadian Congress. â€œWeâ€™re all concerned and thereâ€™s a definitely a shock factor in processing it.â€  Announcing new sanctions on key Russian figures, Justin Trudeau on Thursday condemned the â€œhorrific, unprovoked attackâ€ on Ukraine. â€œWe stand united and steadfast in our support of Ukraineâ€™s sovereignty,â€ the prime minister said. â€œAnd we stand in solidarity with the Ukrainian peopleâ€™s right to decide their own future in a free and democratic state.â€ Canadaâ€™s sanctions will target wealthy Russians, large banks and members of the Russian security council, including the defence minister, the finance minister and the justice minister. Canada will also halt export permits to the country. The deputy prime minister, Chrystia Freeland, who is of Ukrainian descent, said Russian president Vladimir Putinâ€™s decision to invade Ukraine placed him in the ranks of the â€œreviled European dictatorsâ€ who caused mass death and carnage in the 20th century. Airstrikes at dawn as Russia begins â€˜war of aggressionâ€™ with UkraineRead more At times speaking in Ukrainian, Freedland also called on fellow members of the Ukranian Canadian community to show strength and to support loved ones affected by the war. â€œThe Ukrainian people, like all people, must be free to determine their own future,â€ she said. â€œWe know that the people of Ukraine â€¦ are fighting for us too. They are fighting for democracy and we stand with them.â€ Canadaâ€™s new sanctions comes after it previously pledged C$500m (US$780,770) in financial support Ukraine C$7.8m worth of lethal equipment and ammunition. For Ukrainian Canadians, news of the invasion has been devastating. A number of organizations across Canada are quickly raising funds for relief projects, organizing rallies and assisting those with families affected by the war. The prairie province of Alberta announced it would donate C$1m to the Ukrainian Canadian Congress, a recognition of the large diaspora population in the regionâ€“ and the long history Ukrainian residents have farming the area. Kulish, who works closely with humanitarian organizations in Ukraine, says colleagues on the ground have described the surreal experience of shelling near their homes and the constant worry of loved ones. â€œIâ€™ve been checking in with colleagues telling them weâ€™re here. Weâ€™re praying for you. Weâ€™re looking to see what we can do in response. Weâ€™re trying to give them that knowledge that people are concerned about them and who love them,â€ said Kulish. â€œBut you canâ€™t imagine what itâ€™s like. Itâ€™s almost unfathomable.â€ For the last eight years, Kulish has been involved in work providing trauma therapy clinicâ€™s in the countryâ€™s eastern region. â€œWeâ€™ve been living this for the last seven years, so in one way, weâ€™re terribly prepared for it.â€

heading: Russia has invaded Ukraine: what we know so far
text:
Minutes after Vladimir Putin ended weeks of agonised speculation by announcing a â€œspecial military operationâ€ at dawn on Thursday, explosions were heard near major Ukrainian cities, including the capital, Kyiv. According to Ukrainian officials, the initial wave of strikes appeared to involve cruise missiles, artillery and airstrikes, which struck military infrastructure and border positions, including airbases.
Russian troops have entered the country from the north, east and south, seemingly targeting the capital, Kyiv and the cities of Kharkiv and Kherson respectively.
Ukraineâ€™s president, Volodymyr Zelenskiy, responded to the invasion by declaring martial law and saying Kyiv would issue weapons to every Ukrainian who wanted to defend their country. As Ukrainian diplomats pleaded with the world to stop the Russian aggression, Zelenskiy warned of a bleak return to the past.
By mid-afternoon on Thursday, Russiaâ€™s defence ministry claimed to have â€œneutralisedâ€ Ukraineâ€™s airbases and air defences, destroying 74 military ground facilities, including 11 airfields, three command posts and 18 radar stations for anti-aircraft missile systems. Ukrainian authorities said Russia had carried out 203 attacks and that fighting was raging across almost the entire territory. 00:48Explosions hit Ukraine's major airports as Russia begins invasion â€“ video  Thousands of Ukrainians are already on the move and leaving the country, with tens of thousands more preparing to flee, after the Russian attack ordered by Vladimir Putin. Videos and photos on social media show lines of cars moving out of cities and heading west, as well as an increase of people on foot near the southern and western borders.
Joe Biden ordered broad new sanctions targeting four Russian banks, oligarchs and high-tech sectors. The US president also said 7,000 additional troops would be deployed to Germany. â€œPutin is the aggressor,â€ Biden said. â€œPutin chose this war, and now he and his country will bear the consequences.â€
The UKâ€™s prime minister, Boris Johnson, announced the â€œlargest everâ€ set of economic sanctions on Russia, including pushing to end Russiaâ€™s use of the Swift international payment systems, freezing assets of all major Russian banks, limiting cash held by Russian nationals in UK banks, and sanctioning more than 100 individuals and entities.
Ukraineâ€™s foreign minister, Dmytro Kuleba, voiced his anger as EU heads of state and government appeared to hold back from imposing the potentially most damaging sanction on Russia. With casualties mounting, Kuleba warned that European and US politicians would have â€œblood on their handsâ€ if they decided against blocking Russia from the Swift system, through which it receives foreign currency.

heading: Compared with Putin, Boris Johnson is a sociopath we can accept
text: The clues had all been there. The buildup of troops on the Ukrainian border. The increasingly bizarre, stage-managed television appearances of Vladimir Putin. The movement of troops into the self-proclaimed republics in Luhansk and Donetsk. Yet still there was a belief that diplomacy and reason could somehow win through and that Russia would pull back from all-out war. That hope died early on Thursday morning when Putin launched a ground, sea and air offensive on several Ukrainian cities, including the capital, Kyiv. Just after midday, Boris Johnson delivered his own televised statement from behind a small table hastily positioned in front of a doorway in Downing Street. Presumably his office was too much of a tip for him to be filmed there. There was an early reference to Neville Chamberlain, who in a 1938 radio address had described the dispute over the Sudetenland as â€œa quarrel in a faraway country between people of whom we know nothingâ€. Johnson stressed that Ukraine was neither far away nor a country of which we know nothing. But otherwise there was little of the Churchill tribute act that has characterised his recent Commons appearances.  Instead we got something more restrained. More hesitant, even. As if even he couldnâ€™t quite believe it had come to this and was uncertain of what steps to take beyond a vague aspiration to defeat Putin. He talked the talk. Bodies â€“ not ours â€“ would mount up and Russia would be hit with massive sanctions. Yet there was a dissonance. A disconnection. It was almost as if he was aware that these were desperately serious times and he needed a different persona to his naturally glib self. Yet he couldnâ€™t conjure one that was entirely convincing. Johnson did rather better when he faced the Commons to make a statement on Ukraine in the afternoon. Possibly because he had had a quick lesson in statesmanship from a crisis management expert, though more likely because he had accepted a few home truths. This was one of the few occasions when it didnâ€™t matter that most of the country didnâ€™t rate him at all and believed his first instinct was always to protect himself. In a straight fight with a delusional, narcissistic dictator who had just invaded another country and had blood on his hands, the UKâ€™s very own narcissist was going to win hands down. Put simply, Putin was in a totally different league of sociopath. So Johnson only had to stand up to look good. It also helped that this time, Boris actually had something substantial to say.
